Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2008 09:34AM monee wrote: I had radiation to the left breast 9 years ago.  I had two excisions for BC on the right recently.(still don't have clean margins). So, I made the decision to do a bi-lat with immediate recon.  Recon on the radiated side is much more invloved. Preferred methods are to use some sort of flap procedure. In my case, lat flap is best because I am rather thin.  I do not regret doing lumpectomy and radiation nine years ago. Unless there is extensive invlovement, lumpectomy and radiation is standard of care as far as I know. Most of what I read on the recon forum is positive regarding the flap procedures. So if you ever have to do it, it can be done.  Mine is scheduled for October 8th. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Radiation site/skin thanku kyoung1964

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2009 07:09PM monee wrote: I did not want to cut them off.  When the first surgeon recommended a bilat mastectomy I almost fell on the floor. Given the choice I would have kept them.  But in the end, the mastectomy was necessary. I am in the middle of reconstuction now.  The new ones are ok though I would rather have real boobs. And for emotions?...it gets better with time.

Posts.Title: Pain and how this was handled, NOT happy QueenK tigerlili001

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2008 11:43AM monee wrote: I too have decided not to have radiation. I did lumpectomy with rads on the left nine years ago.  Now I have bc on the right.  Although highly recommended, I declined radiation for two reasons. One, the radiation waiting room is a very sad place to be.  While my prognosis is excellent, others there are fighting for their lives.  I felt guilty and sad. Guilty because I had a chance to live and sad because I could not help them.  The second reason is because I have breast implants. The radiation caused severe capsular contracture on the left.  I had the implants replaced but my cosmetic result in my opionion is poor.  I have been living with these water balloons for nine years and I HATE IT. Having radiation on the right is going to cause even worse cosmetic consequences. I have been told many times that the reoccurance rate without radiation is 40 percent. I agree that is high.  But there is a 60 percent chance that I won't get it back. I have not had the nodes evaluated yet.  That happens in three weeks.  Positive nodes would make me reconsider my decision. But as of now, no radiation for me. We all can make our own decisions.
Posts.Title: I have decided NOT to do radiation... OrliNaaman burma

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2009 08:05PM monee wrote: I did rads the first time I had BC.  It was a drag going for treatment.  The treatments were quick.  The worst side effect was the fatigue.  Now nine years later, I had to do a bilateral.  I am glad I had both breasts for these past years.  Once you cut them off, they are gone.  What I have learned most from this site is that the decision for mastectomy is truely a personal one.  Do want feels right for you. Take your time.  Insurance will cover cancer treatment.

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2010 03:37PM monee wrote: I had micromets according to my pathology. I was treated with chemo 4xTC. Age is an important factor to consider as well.  I had Stage 1 in 1999 on one side and Stage II in 2008 with micromets  on the other. I was 40 and 49 at the time.
Posts.Title: Micro-metastasis? Caused by biopsy? dcrm dcrm

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2008 05:24AM monee wrote: The date on my pathology was two days after the surgery.  So I believe the report will be ready.  The doctors can download the reports from the internet.  So if they say it is not ready, it is because they didn't dowload it.  My doc kept mine from me for two weeks! She didn't want to tell me the margins were not clean again.  The doctor will pull the drains right in the office.  Hurts a little. Mine were in 8 days. Average is 7-10 days. I hated the drains. Last time I did this, the drains came out too early and I had to have the fluid drained with a needle twice. Not fun.
